content: @WG-async-foundations meeting!

Agenda:

  • Announcements and ongoing work updates
  • New issue triage (no new issues)
  • Vision process
I don't have any announcements or updates besides the vision, but I want to leave space in case anyone does :)
@triagebot end-topic for that

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
Me and @eholk synchronized today on the issue of "overapproximated lifetimes"
And I believe they plan to work on it
We should assign them to an issue and put the :screw: to them
awesome!
Yup, I'm planning to work on it.
Which issue was it specifically?
there's a bunch
the tracking issue.... which was it?
#69663
Another announcement:
I'm interested in talking to folks who might be inspired to work on the async book
So think about that :)

nikomatsakis said:

the tracking issue.... which was it?

assign the whole tracking issue? ok :)
why not
one of the questions is which bit to focus on first, once we figure that out, we can tweak the assignment
works for me!

nikomatsakis said:

So think about that :)

Oh, @Doc Jones, maybe this works for NaRuWriClu
(National Rust Writing Club, obviously)
need a better thing than National... hmmm.....
InterRuWriClu

nikomatsakis said:

nikomatsakis said:

So think about that :)

Oh, Doc Jones, maybe this works for NaRuWriClu

That would be my hope, yes.
GloRuWriClu?
I like InterRuWriClu, it sounds better when you say it out loud, although I know that "international" is older terminology

tmandry said:

GloRuWriClu?

Easy for you to say.
ok
(for those who don't know, this is a play on NaNoWriMo, the idea is to get together folks to group-write docs with periodic visits from an expert)
anyway
Writing novels though.

Doc Jones said:

tmandry said:

GloRuWriClu?

Easy for you to say.

I think it's easier than InterRuWriClu but that's just me :P
@triagebot end-topic for announcements

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
we have too many bots :)
Bossy bots.

Okay, up next is

Vision doc
OK, so...
I've been working with @tmandry and following up with various other folks (e.g., hat tip to @Carl Lerche, @Yoshua Wuyts, and @Alice Ryhl for really helpful feedback thus far)
and I think the "harmonic synthesis" is finally starting to take shape
I pushed a bunch of new commits that I had hoped to have completely done by now but haven't quite
but still enough to show
Latest draft: https://nikomatsakis.github.io/wg-async-foundations/vision/harmonic.html
But some highlights:
• Key aspects that summarize the way that it should feel, without specifying how we achieve it (see also the How using async Rust should feel page)
They include some indication of how much certainty there is about something :)
@nikomatsakis Will "projects" be a part o the final set of vision docs?
• A mislabeled narrtive page that is really kind of a "async rust user's manual from the future"
which seems to balance out giving a tour of the goals while being able to provide technical details
• A roadmap that lays out the work to be done
and gives some ideas of timeline, as well as the process

one of the key bits is the idea of an evaluation. Particularly for some of the more complex topics, where there are lots of approaches, the idea is to assign someone with the job of narrowing things down to 2 or 3 choices. An owner, per the lang team initiative process.
the roadmap page also includes the rust teams responsible for driving each bit of work (if applicable, some items are "external")
there is a lot of other material in the preview that I haven't finished cleaning up
but e.g. I expect to have each of those "deliverables" link to a page that talks about it (some of that material is already there, just not in the right place), and to have other links here and there

To answer your question, @Doc Jones, I have been debating about just how to incorporate the projects and also the characters/narrative. I really like the "user's manual from the future". I think it would be useful to be able to have a narrative description too, or at least some kind of "key things for each project"
e.g., "what does this mean to you if you work on X"
I'm a bit sad that my user manual doesn't include the characters but then again I really like the format :P

anyway, that's the work that's been done since last week, I think that the next steps are:

  • some more meetings to go over details, additioanl edits (some stuff is missing from there)
  • @tmandry and I plan to be scheduling meetings with the relevant Rust teams to help explain what's going on
oh, one thing I didn't explain
and I haven't written the txt for :)
oh, I guess I did

Some of the projects are in Exploration stage, this basically means: let's have people mess around writing crates and we'll collect them to try and brainstorm what this mgiht look like, because we don't have enoguh experience yet to start doing a proper evaluation

nikomatsakis said:

one of the key bits is the idea of an evaluation. Particularly for some of the more complex topics, where there are lots of approaches, the idea is to assign someone with the job of narrowing things down to 2 or 3 choices. An owner, per the lang team initiative process.

I think this would start by surveying the best approach for the AsyncRead and AsyncWrite traits
as well as the "how can we make scopes able to access borrowed data"
nit: the mdbook uses Experimentation, not exploration
ugh
just in case it's confusing :)
well, whichever one is best :)
I was trying to replace all the titles with emoji but that turned out to be too confusing :)
lol
• ðŸ§ª Experimentation
Is there anything in particular you'd like people in this meeting to focus on for feedback? It's a lot of content :)
yeah, it's a lot
most of it is 'kind of the same'
one thing that did change was in the scopes
and async iterators

before I was talking about something like

scope(|s| {
    foo.buffered(5, s).for_each(...

but in this doc it describes instead having a "rayon-like" parallel async iter approach, so that you write

foo.buffered(5).for_each

and then this buffered combinator can introduce a scope of its own (hat tip to @Yoshua Wuyts for that suggestion)
whcih I think is nicer :)
but that's kind of in the details

tmandry said:

Is there anything in particular you'd like people in this meeting to focus on for feedback? It's a lot of content :)

I guess where I would want the most attention is

  • the high-level ideas, which largely haven't changed
  • the immediate steps on the roadmap
  • the evaluation process

I'd want to know if

  • anything is missing (your pet idea...?)
  • you have interest in helping drive a project, we could talk that over

the idea of the roadmap page, last point, is that the "deliverables" start out high-level and we gradually add more detailed ones as "sub-projects" emerge (e.g., async fn everywhere is fairly well understood, so it has a lot of detail)

nikomatsakis said:

  • anything is missing (your pet idea...?)

I'm brand-spanking-new to these triage meetings, so this might already exist.

but I will say that while working with Async Rust the past few months there have been several moments that I wished for a JavaScript Promise vs Rust Future guide.

How to do X in JavaScript (show code), how to do the same with idiomatic, async Rust (show code)

nikomatsakis said:

I guess where I would want the most attention is

links might help here, I'm trying to cross reference what you said with the different sections in the ToC :)
lol, ok

Chaz Kiker said:

nikomatsakis said:

  • anything is missing (your pet idea...?)

I'm brand-spanking-new to these triage meetings, so this might already exist.

but I will say that while working with Async Rust the past few months there have been several moments that I wished for a JavaScript Promise vs Rust Future guide.

How to do X in JavaScript (show code), how to do the same with idiomatic, async Rust (show code)

This would be great for the async book, I think

Chaz Kiker said:

nikomatsakis said:

  • anything is missing (your pet idea...?)

https://github.com/yoshuawuyts/rust-for-js-peeps
I'm brand-spanking-new to these triage meetings, so this might already exist.

but I will say that while working with Async Rust the past few months there have been several moments that I wished for a JavaScript Promise vs Rust Future guide.

How to do X in JavaScript (show code), how to do the same with idiomatic, async Rust (show code)
Also, @Chaz Kiker, taht's actually quite helpful, I do think that's a good example of what we should suggest in the docs
let me add that :)

That link ended up in a weird spot.
https://github.com/yoshuawuyts/rust-for-js-peeps

One more, with feeling... ok, links...

I guess where I would want the most attention is

  • the high-level ideas, which largely haven't changed
  • the immediate steps on the roadmap
  • the evaluation process

nikomatsakis said:

I'd want to know if

  • anything is missing (your pet idea...?)
  • you have interest in helping drive a project, we could talk that over

You mentioned this to me but one thing that isn't in the roadmap directly is my pet idea, writing code that's usable in both singlethreaded and multithreaded contexts, and looking now I don't see it directly "implied" by anything in the roadmap

Doc Jones said:

https://github.com/yoshuawuyts/rust-for-js-peeps

Yes, like this... but WAY more in-depth... and specifically for JS Promise vs Rust Future (and idiomatic with async and .await and no explicit use of Future)
@tmandry yep, we should talk about where that fits in
it's probably just its own line item for now with a "Far future" label
I had a question, if I have a huge breaking change proposal, is the github repo the correct place to post it, or should I just post it on zulip/internals/etc?
lol
that's a great question :
there are so many big changes in there as is :)
I mean, I guess internals is always a good place to start :)
but throw a link here
I at least never have time to look at internals so....

nikomatsakis said:

it's probably just its own line item for now with a "Far future" label

I wouldn't say it's significantly farther than some other items in the doc, many of them need deep exploration / evaluation, including this one
agreed
that's what I meant, though. :) It's kind of one of those "We're not at that stage yet" items
it "just" depends on integration chalk :P
it seems like there's language design work that could happen in the meantime, but maybe you can already see how it should work
"more or less"
the main reason I bring it up is that it could interact with other lang design items, so it's good to have it in mind at least
it'd be good to spend some time sketching it out
ok, that's all I've got
shall we end then?
@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
ok, thanks all!
Thanks!

@nikomatsakis one other question (and maybe this isn't the place for this) but I'm looking to hop in and get involved with contributing! wondering if there's any specific place/issue that I could be useful.

I'd be happy to draft up a MD file with all the various JS Promise & Async/Await examples that would be worth "mirroring" in Rust, potentially?
@Chaz Kiker that would be awesome!
